title: EchoInk-R1: Exploring Audio-Visual Reasoning in Multimodal LLMs via Reinforcement Learning
author: Zhenghao Xing (The Chinese University of Hong Kong), Xiaowei Hu (Shanghai Artificial Intelligence Laboratory), Chi-Wing Fu (The Chinese University of Hong Kong), Wenhai Wang (Shanghai Artificial Intelligence Laboratory), Jifeng Dai (Tsinghua University), Pheng-Ann Heng (The Chinese University of Hong Kong), ...
relevance_why: The paper introduces reinforcement learning strategies to enhance audio-visual reasoning in multimodal large language models, which could be applicable to improving audio-language models and multi-modal tasks in Haohe Liu's research.
background: The task involves improving multimodal reasoning by integrating audio and visual signals in large language models to enhance question answering capabilities.
contribution: This paper introduces EchoInk-R1, a reinforcement learning framework to enhance audio-visual reasoning in multimodal large language models, achieving 85.77% accuracy on specific tasks with just 562 reinforcement learning steps.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous multimodal models typically struggled with incorporating audio-visual reasoning and relied heavily on unimodal approaches.
technical_comparison.novelty: EchoInk-R1 employs Group Relative Policy Optimization to refine audio-visual reasoning effectively within a unified framework.

key_innovation: The framework leverages lightweight reinforcement learning for structured cross-modal reasoning, facilitating reflective updates and improved decision-making.
real_world_impact: Enhances the ability of models to perform complex assessments in real-world scenarios, such as interactive agents and multimedia retrieval, improving the overall performance of multimodal applications.
limitations: The dataset used for training is limited in scale, and the model may still default to unimodal shortcuts in ambiguous cases.

new_terms.Group Relative Policy Optimization: **Group Relative Policy Optimization** is a reinforcement learning technique that optimizes policies based on the relative rankings of generated responses without requiring a value function, focusing on improving decision quality.
new_terms.aha moments: **Aha moments** refer to instances where a model revisits and corrects its initial assumptions or interpretations due to deeper insights gained from the data.

open_sourcing: Code and dataset are publicly available at https://github.com/HarryHsing/EchoInk
